titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Joseph Freeman papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rebecca J. Mead

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-11-10T12:29-0800

change.item: 2012: Descriptions of reformatted audiovisual items updated.
Revised to update encoding by Samira Bozorgi.

Updated to include increment and restrictions. Revised to have series description in one dsc. March 23, 2004: PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Joseph Freeman Papers)//EN" "reg_095.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

physdesc.extent: 187 manuscript boxes, 3 card file boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 slide box, 1 album box, 40 envelopes, 2 sound discs

did.abstract: Writings, correspondence, printed matter, notes, and photographs relating to the relation between communism and art and literature, and to communism in the United States, Mexico, and the Soviet Union.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies of some sound recordings in this collection are available for immediate access. To listen to other sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Joseph Freeman papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1980.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Reporter, Chicago Tribune and New York Daily News (in Paris and London)
Publicity Director, American Civil Liberties Union
Trip to Russia as New Masses Moscow correspondent
Trip to Mexico as New Masses Mexico correspondent Married Ione Robinson
Author, Voices of October (with Joshua Kunitz and Louis Lozowick)

Speaking and fundraising trips in the United States for the John Reed Clubs and the Communist Party, including accompanying Boris Pilynak to Hollywood (1931) and Henri Barbusse on a tour of the Midwest (1933)
Attended Mexican Writers Conference as delegate of the League of American Writers
Publicity Director, American Civil Liberties Union
Researcher, Information Please (radio show), including a U.S.O. tour in the summer of 1945
Staff member, Edward L. Bernays (public relations firm)
Staff member, Executive Research, Inc. (public relations firm)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Writings, correspondence, printed matter, notes, and photographs, relating to the relation between communism and art and literature, and to communism in the United States, Mexico, and the Soviet Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical sketches, clippings, correspondence, legal documents, printed matter, family material, and miscellany. Arranged alphabetically by form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holographs, drafts, and printed copies of poetical writings by Joseph Freeman, with related notes, correspondence, and other material, arranged chronologically by date of publication, or, that failing, by date of composition.

NOTE: This file contains poetical works by Freeman, with the exception of "Hurrah for Everything!" ("Corrido"), because of its relationship to a larger set of prose works; writings on poetry in prose; and many rough notes and drafts which probably include material relating to the development of poems. All these items are located in the subsequent series, SPEECHES AND WRITINGS (PROSE) FILE.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 914 prints, 31 postcards and 22 slides depicting Joseph Freeman and others, including Henri Barbusse, Earl Browder, Max Eastman, Sergei Eisenstein, Louis Fischer, Ivy Litvinov, Vsevold Meyerhold, Tina Modotti, Red Motley, Jose Clemente Orozco, Boris Pilnyak, Harry Truman, and Oscar Williams, and views of Mexico, Italy, Sudan, Hungary, and the Soviet Union.
See photocard catalog for detailed description.

did.unittitle: 49 prints depicting the Freeman family to
57 prints and 12 duplicates depicting Joseph Freeman,
18 prints and 3 duplicates depicting Joseph Freeman with others,
13 prints and 11 duplicates taken by Tina Modotti, including two inscribed by her, depicting Joseph Freeman and Ione Robinson, a cover for the New Masses, and a puppet maker,
36 prints depicting Ione Robinson in Mexico and elsewhere, including four inscribed to Freeman,

23 prints and 1 duplicate depicting Freeman and others and scenes in Mexico, including two prints depicting Tina Modotti, (one photographed by Edward Weston); 1 print of Josi Clemente Orozco; and 1 inscribed print by Ione Robinson depicting a Diego Rivera mural,
7 prints depicting participants at the Congress of Mexican Artists and Writers,
19 prints and 1 duplicate depicting Joseph Freeman with others in New York, including the staff of the New Masses, (?); and unidentified people and places in New York,
7 prints depicting Charmion von Wiegand, including one photographed by Lotte Jacobi, 2 prints depicting Freeman and Charmion, and 5 prints of scenes of Italy,
38 prints and 8 duplicates depicting Freeman, Charmion von Wiegand, and unidentified friends, ; and their house in Accord, New York,
28 prints depicting bomb damage and scenes of daily life in France during World War II, including one print of Freeman in uniform in France,
15 prints depicting Freeman, Charmion von Wiegand, Ivy Litvinov, and others at a party in honor of Freeman's book, Never Call Retreat,
2 prints and 2 duplicates depicting banquets of the NCFA, including Freeman with others, Boston, Massachusetts, and Harry Truman with Red Motley, St. Louis, Missouri,
6 prints of murals from the Revere Room at the Hotel Lexington, New York City, depicting scenes of the American Revolution, including one scene with Freeman,
10 prints and 6 duplicates depicting literary and political figures, including Henri Barbusse, Louis Fischer, Max Eastman, Oscar Williams, Earl Browder, and Karl von Wiegand,
39 prints and 1 duplicate depicting Mr. and Mrs. Karl von Wiegand and scenes from their travels to Khartoum and Budapest,
25 prints depicting Ivy Litvinov, (?); 5 prints depicting Maxim Litvinov, 8 prints depicting Ivy's family and friends, and 3 prints depicting places in Moscow,
5 prints of Diego Rivera, 2 prints of Ivy Litvinov, and 2 prints of unidentified people,
52 prints depicting Soviet artists and writers, including prints of Maksim Gorky and Boris Pilnyak,
20 prints and 1 duplicate depicting sets of productions by Vsevolod Meyerhold and of productions staged by others at the Meyerhold Theatre, and 1 inscribed print depicting Meyerhold,
20 prints depicting sets of film productions by Sergei Eisenstein, including three prints of Mexican people in costumes photographed by Eisenstein, and 1 of Eisenstein and others in Mexico,
64 prints depicting sets of Russian film productions and performers, including twenty prints for Peter the Great,
5 prints depicting scenes from the film Storm Over Asia by V. Pudovkin,
6 prints depicting Soviet and other art,
6 postcards and 2 duplicates depicting posters and people during the Spanish Civil War
5 prints and 2 negatives of schools in Manzanillo designed by architect Carlos LeDuc,
10 prints of political art depicting workers, 2 prints of demonstrations in Tampa? Florida, and 3 prints of workers and scenes in Duluth, Minnesota,
6 prints depicting store displays of Davidson Bakeries, Chicago, and Gimble Brothers, Philadelphia,
15 prints and 12 postcards depicting Russian ethnic musicians, buildings, and scenes in Russia; and 1 print of Lenin,
15 miscellaneous prints and 13 postcards depicting various people and places, including churches in Russia and the Moles Annual Award Dinner,
114 prints and 1 duplicate depicting unidentified friends,
One album containing 149 prints depicting Joseph Freeman, his family, and friends
